Cowboy: ^The cowboy stands up and walks over.

g-0: ^The cowboy goes back to his table and sits down.

knotName: ^This is the content of the knot.

stitchName: ^This is the content of the stitch that should be embedded within a knot.

c-0: ^Val: But we don't have time for this - don'cha know there's a killer on the loose?!
^Val: You gotta get me outta here.
c-1: ^Val: The one who staughtered most of this damn town!

b: ^Val: Haven't you wondered where everyone's gotten to?

c-1: ^Val: Every day for the past few nights, he's taken another soul.
^Val: I'll be damned if I'm gonna just sit here and wait to be next!

b: ^Val: I saw you pickup the keys.

c-1: ^Val: Quick, throw me the keys and I'll let myself out.
c-2: ^Val: Dammed if I know from sitting in this jail cell.
^Val: All I hear are screams and people running away - like we should be doing!
c-3: ^Val: They're all dead, missing, or have run away for their lives.
^Val: They left me here to rot - I've not had any food or water in almost a day!
^Val: There's something roaming the town and I don't wanna be here when it comes callin'
^Val: Say... how'd you arrive in this town anyhow?

c-0: ^Val: Ah, good to know ol' Charlie is still ok.
^"Well, he's not anymore - seems he was killed just outside town, though his body is missing"
^Val: See? This is exactly what I'm talking about - we're not safe here!
c-1: ^Val: I'm just curious - seeing as Goldenbrook ain't exactly on the beaten track no more.
^Val: You look too clean to have ridden here - so guessing you rolled into town on the coach?
g-0: ^Either way, that stagecoach is our ticket outta this damn town.

c-4: ^What are you in here for, anyway?"
^Val: Oh, the whole thing was a complete misunderstanding.
^Val: I was just looking for some spare food and that crooked Sheriff hauled me in here on some hokey charge.
^Val: Ask anyone in town, (aside) assuming you can find anyone left *alive* that is.
^Val: The Sheriff's got it in for me, I swear.
^Val: ...how about you, stranger? What's your story?

c-0: ^"Just rolled into town by chance - now it seems I'm stuck here."
^Val: Well, welcome to the club, par'ner!
c-1: ^Val: Yeah well, you're nosey like a law man - but you're too finely dressed to wear a badge.

c-5: ^Val: Look... if you let me out, I'll tell you everything I know.
^Val (teasing): Should make for one helluva story.
c-6: ^Val: Look, unless you're getting me outta here - we got nothin' to talk about.

stagecoach: ^>>> It felt like the stagecoach had been rolling since forever.
^>>> Looking out across the plane all you can see is dirt, rocks and the odd cactus rolling by. Just a vast, hot emptiness.
^>>> Ever since being relocated here from the east-coast office, I've been unhappy. The paper promised me I'd get stories of new frontiers and wild encounters. But those days are all but over now.
^>>> The gold rush got people in their droves to cross the entire country with a singular dream: to make their fortune.
^>>> Well, perhaps I'm just as naive as they were.

investigate_sound: ^It sounded like it came from outside, near where the driver sits.

c-0: ^Hmm... maybe he can't hear me from here.
c-1: ^But the next town is still HOURS away.

s0: ^It feels good to stretch my legs... but why did we stop?

c-0:
^"Driver? You oka- what the..."

^<< Show Driver seat close-up, with pick-axe plunged into shadow/blood mark... >>

^Where did the driver go?

^How did this pick-axe get wedged in here?

^And is that... blood?
c-1:
^The horses have all gone.

^Perhaps they bolted when the driver went missing (or worse)?

^How will I get to the next town now?

look_around: ^At first, I thought I was stuck in the middle of nowhere.
^But now that my eyes have adjusted, I can see what seems to be a very old dirt road, that leads off into the distance.

s0: ^Hmmm... can't say I've ever heard of it
^The town looks deserted. It also seems like it was only built yesterday. So, where is everybody?
^To the left, it looks like there is a Jail, Telegraph Office, Saloon and General store.
^And to the right, a Church, Cemetary and path leading into the Hills.

b: ^ I can hear shouting coming from the jail.

^There's a prisoner here.

^Val: Oh thank the Lord, a stranger has come to save me.

^Val: Quick par'ner, let me outta here won'cha? We ain't got much time!

^Val: Hey, where'd ya go? You can't just *leave* me here.

^Val: Don't you see? We gotta get out of this damn town!

c-1: ^Upon checking the drawers, you find a bunch of heavy keys.
c-2: ^Val: Thanks par'ner - you did the right thing.
^*CLONK!* (You feel a large blow to your head)
^Val: Sorry par'ner - but rather you than me, to face that death that's creeping round here.
^You wake to find yourself lying on a bed, inside the jail cell, door wide open.
^Your head is splitting and you can feel a large lump where you were struck.

b: ^ "I knew I shouldn't have trusted him..."

c-4:
^It's a pretty standard holding cell.

^Bars, Bed, Pot ...and also a crumpled note of paper
c-5:
^Milton:

^June 5th 1887,

^Found a no-good drifter who broke into the general store last night.

^Mostly looting for cash & jewellery while they were out of town, but he was also snooping through Mary's diary.

^Holding him the cell until we can arrange trial.

^Does he know too much already? Probably.

^Maybe that's ok - perhaps it's time this town told the truth, for once?

^I know *I'm* tired of enforcing a lie.

^- Sheriff Milton Hayes

s0: ^The place is a bit of a mess - looks like it was left in a hurry.

c-0: ^As far as I can tell, it's still operational.
^Guess there's only one way to find out.
c-1: ^Ok, let's hope someone's still listening on the other end of the line.
^Guess, I'll just have to wait and find out.
^Hmm... looks like there was a telegram waiting to be sent.
c-2: ^"Do not come. They're all dead. Save yourself."
^It appears that this message had yet to be sent.

c-0: ^Look at what you did to Mother Nature's beautiful land.
^Filling rivers and lakes with your poison.

s0: ^Judging by the mess, it looks like some looters have been helping themselves to the store's stock.

c-1: ^Fred was very late to bed last night.
^When I asked where he'd been, he closed me down in a voice that I'd never heard before.
^His face said "anger", but his eyes read "fear".
^Wherever he's been and whatever he's done - I know he would never tell me.
^Guess I'll just have to find out for myself.
c-2: ^A cave-in, that's what they're all saying.
^Someone asked whether he'll get a proper burial, Rev. John assured me he would.
^Though, as the mine was unsafe and now off-limits - Sheriff Hayes would retrieve him alone.
^I asked if his family had been notified, but Henry quickly claimed Thomas had none.
^(Aside) Could've sworn someone said he had a wife back in England...
^Anyway, the funeral is planned for tomorrow.
c-3: ^It was a small, but respectful service.
^Closed casket, due to the result of the cave-in, Sheriff Hayes said.
^It's a pity no other miners could pay their respects.
^But those few remaining are all packing up and leaving due to failed digs.
^Makes me wonder if there's anything left for this town.
^But today's not the day for such thoughts.

s0: ^For such a small town, there seems an awful lot of headstones.

c-2: ^Why on earth would I want to do that?
c-3: ^Guess there's only one way to know for sure...
^The coffin is just full of rocks.
^Why would they bury an empty coffin?

hills: ^It's a trail up to the mine(s).
church: ^There's a bloodstain on the floor, next to the altar.

c-0: ^My heart knows the truth - it always did.
^We could have built this town by other means.
^It was my greed that allowed them all to convince me otherwise.
^We are damned - he is coming for us all.
^May god have mercy on our souls.

flashback_1: ^Thomas: I've made camp in a small settlement called Goldenbrook.
^Thomas: My tent is pitched up in the hills, out of the bustle of the main street.
^Thomas: You should see the view from here, Em - it's a world away from our countryside.
^Thomas: I've staked my claim and digging started last week.
^Thomas: Progress has been slow, but some of us have found a few flakes already.
^Thomas: There IS still gold here - just hope there's enough left for me to bring back home.
^Thomas: Home.  To be so far from home pains me so, but I hope to do you both proud.
^Emily: It is such relief it is to know you are safe, and that prospects are good.
^Emily: I'm sure your son would love to see those gold flakes some day.
^Emily: He told me only the other week that HE wants to sail to America to be a Gold Miner some day.
^Emily: I said we could talk about it when he's older... MUCH older!
^Emily: We miss you, but we are doing fine and are fully behind you.
flashback_2: ^Thomas: Maybe coming over here was a mistake - I feel such a fool.
^Thomas: We haven't found any gold in several weeks.
^Thomas: Plenty of coal deposits, but the gold is elluding us.
^Thomas: So much so that many of my fellow miners have decided to move on to try other towns.
^Thomas: If it comes to that, I'd rather just come home to you - I've been away far too long already.
^Thomas: I am tired, but please know that your letters have been keeping me going through all this.
^Emily: Don't say such things - I am so proud of you for taking this leap.
^Emily: But should you feel it's time to come home - know that we will be waiting for you with arms wide open.
flashback_3: ^Thomas: Can't say more. Bringing it home with me.
